channel.description: Recent content in Popular Culture on Alien Truth Social

item.title: UFO conspiracy theories
item.description:
UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia article discusses various conspiracy theories surrounding Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs), particularly the idea that governments, especially the United States government, are suppressing evidence of extraterrestrial life or technology. It also explores the evolution of these theories, their proponents, and their presence in popular culture and religion.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section introduces the core concept of UFO conspiracy theories: governments concealing evidence of extraterrestrial involvement. It traces the origins of these theories back to pulp science fiction and the “lost continent” myths. The section highlights Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting as a catalyst for widespread UFO reports and the subsequent speculation about secret technologies. Donald Keyhoe is identified as a key figure in popularizing the idea of a government cover-up. The emergence of the “Men in Black” concept is also mentioned. The section further explains how UFO conspiracy theories became more prevalent after the Kennedy assassination, linking his death to aliens. The term “Cosmic Watergate” is introduced to describe the alleged cover-up. The section also mentions the influence of films like Close Encounters of the Third Kind and the introduction of the Roswell incident to a mass audience. The shift from benevolent “space brothers” to malevolent aliens in the 1980s is discussed, along with the connection of UFO cover-ups to alien abductions, cattle mutilations, and the JFK assassination. The section concludes by noting the resurgence of interest in UFO conspiracy theories in the 1990s and 2017 with Leslie Kean’s stories of a Pentagon UFO program.

Mainstream Views ðŸ”—

This section presents the mainstream scientific perspective on UFOs. It acknowledges the historical and cultural prominence of UFO sightings, particularly after World War II and during the Space Age. It mentions government investigations like Project Blue Book and Project Condign, as well as studies by organizations and individuals. The section emphasizes that these investigations have not confirmed claims of extraterrestrial intelligence or other unconventional explanations for UFOs. It highlights that scientists and skeptical organizations offer prosaic explanations, such as natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, and hoaxes. The section also notes that beliefs surrounding UFOs have inspired new religions and that social scientists view the ongoing interest in UFOs as a form of modern folklore and mythology. Benjamin Radford’s argument against the feasibility of a long-term, international UFO cover-up is also presented.

Notable Proponents ðŸ”—

This section identifies key individuals who have promoted UFO conspiracy theories. Donald Keyhoe, Jacque Vallee, J. Allen Hynek, and Stanton Friedman are mentioned as prominent figures from the 1950s to the 1970s. The section also notes that some proponents, like Richard Shaver and Paul Bennewitz, had mental health issues, while others, like Gray Barker, Carl Allen, Richard Doty, Bill Moore, and Ray Santelli, confessed to hoaxes or lies. The violent ends of Morris Jessup, James E. McDonald, and Bill Cooper are also mentioned. The section lists individuals who have suggested that UFO evidence is being suppressed, including Barry Goldwater, Lord Hill-Norton, Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, Gordon Cooper, and Edgar Mitchell. 21st-century proponents such as Paul Hellyer, Garry Nolan, Haim Eshed, Jim Semivan, Harold E. Puthoff, Tom DeLonge, Luis Elizondo, and David Grusch are also mentioned.

In Popular Fiction ðŸ”—

This section explores the presence of UFO conspiracy theories in popular culture. It mentions films like 2001: A Space Odyssey, Easy Rider, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Flight of the Navigator, Total Recall, Independence Day, and Men in Black. Television series such as The X-Files, Dark Skies, and Stargate are also mentioned as featuring government efforts to conceal information about extraterrestrial beings. John Glenn’s appearance on Frasier, where he confesses to a UFO cover-up, is also noted. The Sidney Sheldon novel The Doomsday Conspiracy and the American Horror Story: Double Feature series are also mentioned.

In Religion ðŸ”—

This section examines the connection between UFO conspiracy theories and new religious movements. It identifies the Nation of Islam, Scientology, and Heaven’s Gate as examples of religious groups that have incorporated UFO-related beliefs. Mormon cosmology’s view of inhabited planets is also mentioned. Theosophists and occultists, such as Meade Layne, George Adamski, George Hunt Williamson, and Guy Warren Ballard, are discussed as early proponents of extraterrestrial contact. The Nation of Islam’s concept of The Mother Plane is also explored. The section also mentions UFO religions such as Unarius, the Aetherius Society, RaÃ«lism, and the Order of the Solar Temple. The Heaven’s Gate mass suicide, linked to the Hale-Bopp comet, is also discussed.

Chronology of UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section provides a detailed timeline of the development of UFO conspiracy theories, starting with Raymond Palmer’s pulp magazine in the 1940s.

1940s Origin in Raymond Palmer’s Pulp Magazine ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on Raymond Palmer, the editor of Amazing Stories, and his role in popularizing UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions his hiring of Kenneth Arnold to investigate the Maury Island incident and the magazine’s claims of a cover-up.

Spaceships of “The Shaver Mystery” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses Richard Shaver’s stories of a secret underground race and their spaceships, published in Amazing Stories. It mentions Palmer’s argument that governments were aware of spaceships visiting Earth.

Kenneth Arnold Ignites Flying Disc Craze ðŸ”—

This subsection covers Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting and the subsequent “flying disc craze.” It mentions the Roswell incident and Palmer’s investigation of the Maury Island report.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the aftermath of the 1947 flying disc craze, including Palmer’s linking of the sightings to Shaver’s claims and Shaver’s prediction that the truth about the discs would remain secret. It also mentions Palmer’s later linking of UFOs to the JFK assassination and Watergate.

National Coverage in the 1950s ðŸ”—

This section discusses the increase in governmental and civilian investigative efforts and reports of public disinformation and suppression of evidence.

Aztec “Alien Bodies” Hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection details the Frank Scully’s claims of recovered alien bodies from crashed flying saucers and the subsequent exposure of the hoax by True magazine.

Air Force Accounts ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the Air Force’s response to UFO sightings, including General John Samford’s press conference and the Robertson Panel’s recommendation for public education. It also mentions Al Chop’s role as a press officer for Project Bluebook and the film Unidentified Flying Objects: The True Story of Flying Saucers.

“Philadelphia Experiment” Hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the Morris K. Jessup’s book The Case for the UFO and the “Philadelphia Experiment” hoax, involving Carl Meredith Allen’s letters and annotations.

‘Men in Black’ Legends ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the origin of the “Men in Black” concept in Gray Barker’s book They Knew Too Much About Flying Saucers.

1960-70s: Growing Distrust in Government ðŸ”—

This section discusses the increasing government skepticism during the 1960s and 1970s, fueled by events like the Kennedy assassination, the Pentagon Papers, and the Watergate scandal.

Fred Crisman and JFK Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This subsection covers Jim Garrison’s prosecution of Clay Shaw and the involvement of Fred Crisman, linking UFO conspiracy theories to the Kennedy assassination.

“Cosmic Watergate” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the concept of a “Cosmic Watergate,” with J. Allen Hynek’s accusations of a government cover-up.

Alien Bodies at “Hangar 18” ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the legends of alien bodies stored at “Hangar 18” at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base.

“Alien Abductions” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the emergence of alien abduction reports, starting with the Betty and Barney Hill case and the Travis Walton incident.

Close Encounters of the Third Kind ðŸ”—

This subsection examines the influence of the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind on UFO conspiracy theories.

Jesse Marcel and Roswell ðŸ”—

This subsection covers Jesse Marcel’s changing statements about the Roswell incident and the increasing attention given to the story by the National Enquirer.

Doty and Lear Promote the “Dark Side” ðŸ”—

This section discusses the shift towards “ufology’s dark side” in the 1980s, with Richard Doty and John Lear promoting theories of government collusion with evil aliens.

Cattle Mutilations and Quiet Helicopters ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the connection between cattle mutilations, UFO sightings, and “quiet helicopters” in the Colorado-New Mexico border region.

Doty Deceives Mutiliation Researchers ðŸ”—

This subsection covers Richard Doty’s deception of Paul Bennewitz and Linda Moulton Howe, feeding them false stories of a UFO conspiracy.

Doty and Bill Moore Spread Bogus MJ-12 Docs ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the spread of fabricated Majestic 12 documents by Richard Doty and Bill Moore.

Lear Promotes Bill Cooper and Bob Lazar ðŸ”—

This subsection explores John Lear’s promotion of Bill

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_conspiracy_theory

item.title: Ancient astronauts in popular culture
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts in Popular Culture ðŸ”—

This article explores the presence of the ancient astronaut theory in various forms of fiction, including literature, comics, television, film, documentaries, music, and video games. The theory posits that extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in the distant past and influenced the development of human civilization.

Literature ðŸ”—

This section details numerous literary works that incorporate the ancient astronaut theme. Some key examples include:

  • Les Xipehuz (1887) by J.-H. Rosny aÃ®nÃ©: Features geometric aliens encountered by primitive humans.
  • Edison’s Conquest of Mars (1898) by Garrett P. Serviss: Martians enslaved inhabitants of the Fertile Crescent and used them to build monuments in Egypt.
  • The Call of Cthulhu (1926) and At the Mountains of Madness (1931) by H.P. Lovecraft: Deals with ancient aliens.
  • 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968) by Arthur C. Clarke: Based on his short story “Encounter in the Dawn,” explores the idea of extraterrestrial influence on human evolution.
  • The Sirens of Titan (1959) by Kurt Vonnegut: Human development is manipulated by aliens to relay messages.
  • Known Space (1964â€“present) by Larry Niven: Humanity is descended from aliens called the Pak.
  • Heechee Saga (1972â€“2004) by Frederik Pohl: The Heechee are an ancient alien race that left behind futuristic technology.
  • Uplift Universe (1980-…) by David Brin: Explores the idea that all species were brought to sapience through the intervention of a galactic “patron.”
  • VALIS trilogy (1981) by Philip K. Dick: An ancient astronaut race placed an information-streaming satellite in orbit around Earth.
  • Encounter With Tiber (1996) by Buzz Aldrin and John Barnes: Deals with the discovery of ancient alien encounters on Earth and Mars.
  • Outlanders novel series (1997-…) by Mark Ellis: The Anunnaki are revealed to have been behind a nuclear war and the Root Race of the Gray aliens.

Comics ðŸ”—

This section highlights comic books and series that feature ancient astronauts or related concepts. Some notable examples include:

  • Uncle Scrooge #34 (1961): A Carl Barks story where Scrooge McDuck’s family discovers a planetoid inhabited by beings who were the basis for Roman and Norse gods.
  • Tales of Suspense #50 (1964): Introduces the Mandarin’s rings, created by the alien Makluans.
  • The Adventures of Tintin: Flight 714 to Sydney (1968) by HergÃ©: Features a temple built to honor ancient astronauts.
  • The Eternals: Deals with advanced aliens (the Celestials) who experimented on early hominids, creating the Eternals and Deviants.
  • Thorgal series by Grzegorz RosiÅ„ski and Van Hamme: The main protagonist is the son of ancient astronauts.
  • KarmatrÃ³n y los Transformables by Oscar GonzÃ¡lez Loyo: Relies heavily on the ancient astronaut theory.

Television ðŸ”—

This section details television shows that have explored the ancient astronaut theme. Some key examples include:

  • Quatermass and the Pit (1958â€“1959): A miniseries that used a version of the ancient astronaut idea.
  • Star Trek: The franchise has numerous examples of extraterrestrials visiting Earth in past centuries, influencing pre-modern humans.
  • Doctor Who: Pyramids of Mars (1975): Features a conflict between aliens of a race named the Osirans forming the basis of Egyptian mythology.
  • Space: 1999 (1975â€“1977): Many alien species have controlled or visited Earth in the past.
  • Battlestar Galactica: Depicts humans as having originated on the planet Kobol and later settled thirteen colony planets, Earth being the last and most distant.
  • Babylon 5 (1993â€“1998): Many of the First Ones, particularly the Vorlons and Shadows, visited Earth at various times in history.
  • The X-Files (1993â€“2002, 2016â€“2018): Has borrowed the ancient astronaut theory.
  • Earth: Final Conflict (1997â€“2002): The Atavus species traveled to Earth in the distant past and ruled over it.
  • The Super Dimension Fortress Macross (1982): Features an ancient alien civilization called The Protoculture, who created the human race on Earth.
  • Neon Genesis Evangelion: Lilith and Adam were two extraterrestrial beings that landed on Earth and gave birth to humanity.

Film ðŸ”—

This section lists films that incorporate the ancient astronaut theory. Some notable examples include:

  • 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968): The first act of the movie features paleocontact.
  • Horror Express (1972): An extraterrestrial is found frozen for millions of years.
  • Alien vs. Predator (2004): The Predator race traveled to Earth at a prehistoric time and had a human culture serve them as Gods.
  • Prometheus (2012): Themed around a group of scientists who set out to discover the origins of human life, which was seeded on Earth and influenced by an ancient race of aliens.
  • Hangar 18 (1980): Involves a UFO whose symbols are found to match those used in ancient cultures.
  • Stargate (1994): Features Ra, a member of the alien species Goa’uld that came to Earth around 8000 BC, enslaved the ancient Egyptians, adopting their culture and religion and posing as their God.
  • Mission to Mars (2000): Another movie with an “alien seeding” theme.
  • Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008): Links the existence of crystal skulls to beings that were perceived as gods by the Maya civilization.

Documentaries ðŸ”—

This section lists documentaries that explore the ancient astronaut theory.

  • Chariots of the Gods (1970)
  • In Search of Ancient Astronauts (1973)
  • In Search of Ancient Mysteries (1974)
  • The Outer Space Connection (1975)

Music ðŸ”—

This section highlights musical works that deal with the ancient astronaut concept.

  • A Spaceman Came Travelling by Chris de Burgh: Deals with the concept of an ancient astronaut, in this case pertaining to the Christ story.
  • Inca Roads by Frank Zappa: Deals with Ancient Astronaut Theory.
  • Several songs by The Lost Children of Babylon: Explicitly state that “Jesus Christ was really an ancient astronaut.”
  • God Is an Astronaut: A post-rock musical group from Ireland with a name exploiting the theory.
  • Ayreon albums: About ancient astronauts, that go by the name Forever, who traveled from the Andromeda Galaxy to earth long ago and influenced the development of science and technology.

Video Games ðŸ”—

This section lists video games that incorporate the ancient astronaut theme.

  • Spore (2008): Has many elements of ancient astronauts, even giving player the ability to manipulate other less developed species as a space travelling species.
  • Final Fantasy VII: Features an ancient astronaut, Jenova, as the main antagonist.
  • Halo series: Ancient humanity was a spacefaring society technologically superior to modern humanity.
  • Dark Void: Features a race of humanoid shape-shifters called Watchers, who ruled over ancient humans as gods.
  • Mass Effect: Humanity discovers a cache of alien technology built by an alien species known as the Protheans.
  • Assassin’s Creed franchise: Humanity was originally created as a slave race by the “First Civilization.”
  • Rise of Nations: Rise of Legends: The Cuotl is a nation of Mesoamerica-inspired tribes subjugated by four extraterrestrial beings who install themselves as deities.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_astronauts_in_popular_culture
